Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: This morning, I woke to the smell of incense and the sound of my mother humming an old family song. Today is the day we honor our ancestors, a tradition my family holds sacred. My parents expect me to be present, to help prepare offerings and recite prayers, just as generations before us have done. But as I help set the table, I remember that my voter ID is still at home, across town. The polls close tomorrow, and today is my only chance to retrieve it before work swallows my time. My father catches my distracted gaze and reminds me, “Family comes first, always.” I nod, feeling the weight of his words. Yet, I can’t ignore the civic duty pressing on my mind—the expectation to participate in shaping our country’s future. My heart pounds as I weigh the disappointment in my parents’ eyes against the responsibility I feel as a voter. The clock ticks, and I stand at the threshold, torn between honoring my family’s traditions and fulfilling my role as a citizen.
